questions.question:
Question 1: Levothyroxine/liothyronine acts by binding to thyroid receptors. Thyroid hormone receptors 
belong to which of the following class of receptors?

options.a: Transmembrane receptor linked to tyrosine kinase

questions.explanation:
Thyroid hormone receptors belong to the class of nuclear receptors. Nuclear receptors are a family of ligand-regulated transcription factors that are activated by 
various lipid-soluble signals, including retinoic acid, thyroid hormone, and steroid hormones. 
They primarily function as transcription factors and directly interact with the genomic DNA to 
regulate gene expression. Nuclear receptors can either remain anchored in the cytoplasm via chaperone proteins until freed 
by ligand-binding (e.g., steroid and vitamin D receptors) or can reside in the nucleus bound to 
specific DNA response elements even in the absence of ligand (e.g., thyroid hormone, PPAR, and 
retinoic acid receptors).

questions.question:
Question 3: A 23-year-old hypothyroid patient taking levothyroxine regularly has now become pregnant. 
What would your advice be regarding levothyroxine?

options.a: Switch to liothyronine as levothyroxine is teratogenic
options.b: Increase the dose as pregnancy causes an increased demand for levothyroxine
options.c: Continue the same dose but monitor the serum levels on a fortnightly basis
options.d: Stop levothyroxine till the end of the first trimester as it has teratogenic potential

questions.explanation:
The dose of levothyroxine in patients who become pregnant should usually be increased. This is 
because demand for levothyroxine increases in pregnancy and low thyroxine levels are associated 
with adverse fetal outcomes such as mental retardation. The dose of levothyroxine is increased by 30-50% by asking the patient to take 2 extra pills per 
week. Increased demand for levothyroxine in pregnancy is due to: • The increased serum concentration of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) induced by estrogen • Increased expression of type 3 deiodinase in the placenta • A small amount of passage of levothyroxine to the fetus Thyroid hormones are not teratogenic. Liothyronine is not preferred in pregnancy because T3 has 
a short half-life and requires frequent dosing to limit large fluctuations in levels. In addition, 
excess T3 often acts to normalize TSH while lowering T4, thereby risking inadequate T4 
availability to the fetus.

questions.explanation:
Patients who start estrogen therapy will need to increase their thyroid supplementation doses. Estrogens raise the circulating levels of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG), thereby increasing the 
bound fraction and decreasing the free (bioactive) fraction of circulating thyroxine (T4). As a 
consequence, estrogen therapy increases the T4 supplementation requirements of women being 
treated for primary hypothyroidism. Drugs increasing TBG levels: • Estrogens • Tamoxifen • Methadone • 5-fluorouracil Drugs decreasing TBG levels: 615 
Sold by @itachibot • Androgens • Corticosteroids • Niacin Drugs decreasing binding of T4 to TBG (by displacement): • Salicylates (aspirin, mefenamic acid) • Heparin • Furosemide

questions.question:
Question 5: A 45-year-old patient suffering from Graves disease has been on treatment for the past three 
weeks. She has now developed fever and sore throat with an absolute neutrophil count of 80 
neutrophils per microlitre of blood. The use of which of the following drugs can result in such 
a clinical picture?
questions.explanation:
This patient is suffering from agranulocytosis which is a serious adverse effect that can be seen 
with the use of either methimazole or propylthiouracil. Agranulocytosis usually occurs in the initial weeks or months of therapy. It occurs rapidly and 
periodic monitoring of granulocyte levels is generally ineffective. However, it is reversible on discontinuation of the drug. Therefore, patients who are on these 
drugs should be instructed to report immediately if they develop fever or sore throat.

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient developed thyroid storm in the post-operative ward and was immediately started on 
IV propranolol and a loading dose of propylthiouracil. The antithyroid drug acts by inhibiting 
which of the following deiodinases?
questions.explanation:
Propylthiouracil inhibits only type I deiodinase (D1). Deiodinases are the enzymes that are involved in the peripheral conversion of T4 to either T3 or 
reverse T3. Type I deiodinase (D1) and type II deiodinase (D2) convert T4 to T3. Type III (D3) is 
involved in the conversion of T4 to reverse T3. Note: Amiodarone inhibits both types I and type II deiodinases. 616 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A 40-year-old man presented with complaints of increased sweating and weight loss over the 
past two months. On examination, he is tachycardic, has exophthalmos, and a diffusely 
enlarged thyroid gland. Which of the following is the drug of choice for the management of 
this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Graves disease and the drug of choice is methimazole. Option A: Methimazole is preferred over propylthiouracil due to fewer side effects and single-daily 
dosing (compared to PTU which is given TID). Option C: Levothyroxine is used in hypothyroidism. Option D: Lugol's iodine is a thyroid hormone-release inhibitor but not used as a first-line drug.

questions.question:
Question 8: A 23-year-old primiparous woman presented with features suggestive of thyrotoxicosis, at 7 
weeks of gestation. Which of the following is the drug of choice for the treatment of her 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The drug of choice for the treatment of thyrotoxicosis during the first trimester of pregnancy is 
propylthiouracil (PTU). It is because it has lower teratogenic effects than carbimazole or 
methimazole. Carbimazole and methimazole are associated with teratogenic effects such as: • Aplasia cutis congenita • Choanal atresia • Treacheosopageal fistula • Fetal goiter However, propylthiouracil use is limited to the first trimester due to the risk of hepatotoxicity. It 
is replaced with carbimazole or methimazole in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters of the pregnancy. The lowest effective antithyroid drug dose should be used throughout gestation. This is to 
maintain the maternal serum-free T4 level in the upper limit of the non-pregnant normal 
reference range. Radioiodine therapy is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following statements best describes the Wolff-Chaikoff effect?

options.a: Decrease in thyroid hormone release due to low doses of iodine
options.b: Increase in thyroid hormone release due to high doses of iodine
options.c: Decrease in thyroid hormone synthesis due to high doses of iodine
options.d: Increase in thyroid hormone synthesis due to low iodine intake

questions.explanation:
The Wolff-Chaikoff effect is best described as iodine-induced hypothyroidism. It is a normal, protective downregulation of thyroid hormone synthesis and release via transient 
inhibition of iodide organification in the presence of an iodine load (exogenous supplementation, 
iodinated contrast dye, drugs like amiodarone). This occurs in the thyroid gland which is under 
pituitary control. With persistent high iodine load, an escape phenomenon occurs in normal individuals after 
around 10 days as the iodide levels fall inside the follicle. In autoimmune diseases (Hashimoto’s or 
Grave’s), however, the suppression may persist. 617 
Sold by @itachibot The Jod-Basedow phenomenon is iodine-induced hyperthyroidism. It is also seen after an iodine 
load. However, it is seen in thyroid glands where autoregulation and pituitary control have failed. 
When exposed to an iodine load in excess, instead of blocking the organification process, the 
thyroid gland (areas of the autonomously functioning gland) continues to uptake the iodine, 
producing more thyroid hormone independent of normal regulatory mechanisms. It is seen in 
endemic goiter, toxic multinodular goiter, thyroid adenoma, and sometimes in Grave’s disease.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient suffering from Graves disease is posted for thyroidectomy. He is administered 
iodides preoperatively. What is the primary benefit of administrating iodides in this patient?

options.b: To make the gland firm and less vascular

questions.explanation:
The primary benefit of the preoperative use of iodides in Grave’s disease is to make the gland firm 
and less vascular. This makes manipulation and surgical resection easier. Antithyroid drugs like methimazole or carbimazole are indicated to render the patient euthyroid.

questions.question:
Question 11: A patient suffering from hyperthyroidism is administered a drug that acts by inhibiting the 
release of thyroid hormone. Identify the drug.
questions.explanation:
Potassium iodide inhibits the release of the thyroid hormone. Iodides of sodium and potassium and Lugol's iodine act by inhibiting thyroid hormone release. 
Hence, they are also called thyroid constipating agents. They are the fastest-acting agents. The beneficial effect of iodides peaks over 10-15 days and gradually disappears. Tolerance is hence 
an issue with the use of iodides.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 43-year-old lady with papillary thyroid cancer is being treated with radioactive iodine 131. 
What is the half-life of this isotope?
questions.explanation:
The half-life of radioactive I 131 is 8 days I131 emits both beta and gamma rays. It is used both for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes for 
thyroid disorders. I127 is the stable isotope of iodine. I123 is the radioactive isotope of iodine that emits only gamma rays. The action is short-lived with 
a half-life of around 13 hours. It is indicated for diagnostic indications only.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following statements about Lugol's iodine is incorrect?

options.a: Used to make thyroid gland less vascular
options.b: Used to block thyroid hormone release rapidly
options.d: Augments radioactive iodine uptake into thyroid gland

questions.explanation:
Lugol's iodine does not augment the uptake of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland. Radioactive iodine uptake into the thyroid gland is reduced by Lugol's iodine as the uptake is 
inversely proportional to the serum concentration of stable iodine. Lugol's iodine makes the thyroid gland less vascular and firmer. It blocks the release of thyroid 
hormone. The beneficial effect peaks over 10-15 days and gradually disappears. Therefore 
tolerance is an issue. 618 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A 40-year-old lady who is a known case of Graves disease was posted for thyroidectomy. 
During the surgery, she developed hyperthermia, agitation and the monitors showed an 
arrhythmia. She was managed with aggressive IV fluid therapy, ice packs, and multiple drugs. 
Which of the following drugs that were used, do not inhibit the peripheral conversion of T4 to 
T3?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of a thyrotoxic crisis/thyroid storm. Potassium iodide does 
not inhibit the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. The major action of potassium iodide is the inhibition of hormone release. It is usually given 1 
hour after PTU administration to avoid iodine stimulating thyroid hormone synthesis. Drugs inhibiting the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 are: • Propranolol • Glucocorticoids • Propylthiouracil • Amiodarone • Iopanoic acid 619 
Sold by @itachibot Corticosteroids
